channel.title: 'Special' characters in Java
channel.description:
Hello,
When I looked at some Java code (from the rs loginApplet), I noticed a few things I don't understand, could someone explain the use following characters to me?
[code]if(i1 >= 65 && ~i1 >= -91)[/code] Here: the ~
[code]ua.f = 1 + ua.f & 0x7f;[/code] Here: the 0x7f (it's a color?)
[code]return i1 / 7 | (i1 / 3 << 0xc741b410 | i1 / 4 << 0x8e7aec8);[/code] Here: the <<, the | and the 0x8e7aec8
[code]throw q.a(runtimeexception, "i.A(" + (ma1 == null ? "null" : "{...}") + ',' + i1 + ',' + j1 + ',' + k1 + ')'); [/code] Here the highlighted: (ma1 == null [b][u]?[/u][/b] "null" [b][u]:[/u][/b] "{...}")
Please explain those to me.
Thanks in advance,
Supamagier.
:D

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @quest_rs quest rs
item.description:
@quest_rs wrote:

yes
0b = binary
0x = hex

binary = 2 (0-1)
octal = 8 (0-7)
decimal = 10 (0-9)
hexadecimal = 16 (0 - 9, A-F)

Anything over Hexa (or was it base 32), you use rest of the alphabets ? (okay I forget this bit)

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

follow the numeric procession and it is easy to see what is going on

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

quote=“BAsh(CntLgn), post:3, topic:206737”

The 0x8e7aec8 is hexadecimal. 0=0, 1=1,…9=9,10=A,11=B,12=C,13=D,14=E,15=F,16=10,17=11[/quote]
16=10 and 17=11? As far as I know, hexa goes to F, like you said. Hexa means 16, right, like binair, bi = 2.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

colours are usually easy to identify because they are only ever used near graphics

the name of the beast that is ?: is the ternary operator

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

Than what this does?

i1 / 3 << 0xc741b410 | i1 / 4 << 0x8e7aec8

Or better,what is this in ‘normal’ java?

And what other things ‘cause fear’?
All the classes, colors and names?

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Bitwise nots are easy to remove. Its the rest of the obbing that they are doing that cause fear.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Jagex’s obfuscater is putting bitwise nots in almost every conditional statement now.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

Okay, thank you very much guys, I don’t really understand the << and >>, but I don’t think it’s used much, or really useful, is it? That a?b:c may be very useful, thanks for that.

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

[quote=“supamagier, post:1, topic:206737”]return i1 / 7 | (i1 / 3 << 0xc741b410 | i1 / 4 << 0x8e7aec8);
Here: the <<, the | and the 0x8e7aec8[/quote]
If its a long you & it with 63. If its a int you & it with 31. This is the real shift value.

The 0x8e7aec8 is hexadecimal. 0=0, 1=1,…9=9,10=A,11=B,12=C,13=D,14=E,15=F,16=10,17=11

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

0x7F is hexidecimal (base 16) for the number 127

<< and >> are bit shifts, shift left and shift right respectivly, read up on bitwise operations

~ is bitwise NOT, change every 0 to 1, and vis versa

the (n == null ? heh : non)

that a quick way of boolean operations, its like this

if(n == null)
  return heh;
else
  return non;

like this

String word = (something == 5 ? “something was 5” : “something was not 5”);

Read full topic

item.title: 'Special' characters in Java
item.dc:creator: @supamagier supamagier
item.description:
@supamagier wrote:

Hello,

When I looked at some Java code (from the rs loginApplet), I noticed a few things I don’t understand, could someone explain the use following characters to me?

if(i1 >= 65 && ~i1 >= -91)

Here: the ~

ua.f = 1 + ua.f & 0x7f;

Here: the 0x7f (it’s a color?)

return i1 / 7 | (i1 / 3 << 0xc741b410 | i1 / 4 << 0x8e7aec8);

Here: the <<, the | and the 0x8e7aec8

throw q.a(runtimeexception, "i.A(" + (ma1 == null ? "null" : "{...}") + ',' + i1 + ',' + j1 + ',' + k1 + ')');
Here the highlighted: (ma1 == null ? “null” : “{…}”)

Please explain those to me.

Thanks in advance,

Supamagier.

Read full topic
